I should have gone across the street at the hilton. However, on a positive note, the bell boys were very helpful in recommending local places to eat.

We checked in after a few problems with our reservation. Our family of 5 was relegated to one bedroom after having booked 2, but nevertheless we made it work. This Holiday Inn is off the beaten path to Waikiki, but close enough to walk. We usually pick Holiday Inn's when staying across the States and are almost always satisfied with our stay. This one, however, didn't quite meet our expectations. I guess most hotels in Honolulu are pricey for what you get, and even then, they aren't always the best quality. You can basically expect a not-very-nice H.I. 3 star. I would downgrade it to a 2 star, but it is still clean..and the beds were comfortable enough I guess. Just do the mental degrade on the star rating, and you shouldn't have any surprises with what you're expecting and what you end up getting.

This is a basic, clean, no frills hotel. We had stayed there 11 years ago and were pleased to see that standards had been maintained. Our room on the 14th floor overlooked Ala Moana Boulevard and we were pleased that there was minimal traffic noise. There was some construction across the street but we experienced no noise from it. Our room consisted of two queens, a fridge, coffee maker (with free coffee), a television with limited free channels (pay movies and games were available), storage space for clothes was a bit limited but sufficent for the two of us. If there were more people in the room this may have been a problem on a long stay. Most rooms do not have balconies which may be an issue for some. It is about a 10 minute walk to the beach behind the Hilton Hawaiian Village. The main bonus for us was the cleanliness of the room and all of its fixture, linens, towels etc. Also the price $118 per night. All members of staff we encountered were extremely polite, friendly and helpful. The pool is quite small but by comparision the deck area was large. We didn't use the pool (the beach is too nice to lie by the pool) and in fact we never saw anyone using the pool area. Adjacent to the pool area is a small fitness room which seemed to have adequate equipment and was being used. There is a chinese buffet restaurant at the front of the hotel which didn't look very appetising to us but seemed to be popular at times. There is a small gift shop and a tour desk in the hotel. Within walking distance of the hotel there is a wealth of restaurants, fast food establishments and shops. Restaurants nearby are Outback Steakhouse, Red Lobster, Kobe Steakhouse, Shanghai Bistro, Wailana Coffee House, Singha and Todai. For fast food there is McDonalds, Subway and a little Sushi place in the Discovery Bay Centre. There is also a nice sports bar in the Discovery Bay Centre which also serves food. Also close by you have two ABC stores. The Ala Moana Shopping Centre is about 10 minutes walk away as is the Hard Rock Cafe.

We stayed at the Holiday Inn Waikiki for 7 nights at the end of August 2006. We were on the 10th floor. The room was average size but was clean. The hotel is old and there are no frills but it met our needs. The price was good ($100/night). The hotel had a decent fitness center. The swimming pool was hardly used by the other guests so we had the pool to ourselves most of the time. The hotel is in a good location. It was 15 minute walk from Ala Moana Beach Park which my kids (3 years and 7 years old) loved since there were no waves at this beach. This beach was not crowded so it was just what we were looking for. Across the beach is the Ala Moana Shopping Center. The food at the Ala Moana shopping center was good and the prices were reasonable. We ate most of our meals there. The hotel is also within walking distance (about 15 minutes) to Internation Market (for shopping and food.Overall, we enjoyed our stay. The hotel was not fancy but clean and comfortable and was in a good location. It's outside of Waikiki but close enough to walk to. The staff are friendly and helpful. If we go back to Honolulu, we would stay here again.

We stayed 5 nights in August 2006 and enjoyed the stay. The place has been around a while and shows its age here and there but is well maintained. The staff was friendly and helpful. The woman directing traffic in the parking lot was great. It's a couple miles from the heart of Waikiki, but it was a great value and we had no trouble walking or driving to Waikiki and around the rest of O'ahu from here.

My boyfriend and I stayed here for a week at the end of April and were very happy with our stay. The rooms were nice and clean and all of the staff were very friendly and accomodating.There is a tour desk in the hotel to help with any excursion plans and the staff are more than happy to recommend restaurants and attractions to you.There is a Chinese restaurant attached to the hotel, but we didn't find it had a very appealing breakfast or good selection for the other meals. There is, however, a place about a block away called the Wailana Coffee House that is open 24hrs/day and has an excellent selection for all meals and breakfast is available all day. There is also a great sushi place across the street from the coffee house and many other restaurants in the area as well from seafood to steak to burgers.The hotel is not on the beach, but does have a nice outdoor pool. If you want to go to the beach it is only a 5-10 minute walk by cutting through the Hilton Hawaiian Village hotel. All beaches in Hawaii are, by law, public so it is not a problem to use another hotel's beach.Overall, we found the Holiday Inn to be a very nice hotel. There were no frills or extras, but for a place to sleep while we enjoyed all that Hawaii had to offer, we found it to be very reasonably priced and more than adequate to fit our needs. We would definitely stay here again.

It is a good hotel, but a little far from the "action" of Waikiki. Parking is $12/day which I think it a little high, but since the hotel rates are around the $100/night range, paying for parking isn't that big a deal. Also, the parking that the hotel does have is very limited. I saw it fill up at night and I wondered where the rest of the hotel guests parked. The hotel is very difficult to find if you follow the directions on its web site (I would call ahead to get directions before leaving from HNL). The rooms are average, but I couldn't find a free wireless signal for my PDA...there was only a wired option in the room. :(

We stayed at this hotel for 3 nights and were very happy with the experience. All staff were very friendly and helpful. Our room was very clean and comfortable, we asked for one away from Ala Moana Blvd noise, so it was also QUIET! This hotel is not the most new or flash around, (the hairdriers in the bathroom are ancient) but we spent US$100 per night for a king non smoking room and felt we got value for money. The room has a coffeemaker with coffee provided, a fridge, TV, alarm clock etc.There is a nice pool on level 2 - we spent some time here instead of the beach due to recent sewage spillage in the Ala Wai canal.We did not try the Chinese restaurant onsite but walked a block to a 24hr diner which was a good one. There are also many other restaurants nearby.This hotel is 5 minutes walk from the Ala Moana Center and Convention Center, also Ala Moana Beach Park. Overall a really good hotel for the price.

Good value for $100/night in Waikiki area. Stayed one night after NCL cruise. Dated but clean and comfortable room. Air China and JAL crews stay here so standards have to be kept! Easy to find (follow Convention Centre signs)off H1 from airport. Parking (hotel has window stickers) at rear of hotel for $8/night. Cheap 24hr diner close(turn left out of hotel,50yds) or self service Chinese restaurant on site.

Shops and restaurants are accessible within walk distance, but the hotel is not convenient to most of the attractions in Honolulu. Walking to Waikiki takes more than 20 minutes. It's almost impossible to have a sea view from your room, only if you take the room on very top floors. Don't expect too much about this~~The only thing met my expectation is the price. However if I go to Haiwaii next time, I would pay a little more to stay in a hotel with better facilities and service.

Stayed there for 3 nights after spending a week in a conference in Hilton Hawaiian Village. Of course the contrast was there and it wasn't quite the same thing. But I think the value was very good. It's still relatively close to the beach and the room was ok. View was less pleasant, but when you're in Honolulu you don't stay in the room that much.

Stayed at the HI, Waikiki in March 05.Made very welcome by the staff. Stayed with my wife and 2 kids.Booked Penthouse Room with Balcony. Very Nice Room and Cheap.Swiming pool was very cold but was ideal been next to laundry, We could all swim while waiting for washer.Towels to take to beach or pool were available from Hotel.Kids didn't like the Buffet Breakfast but plenty of places around the corner.Including McDonalds.Location is on the edge of Waikiki which I thought was great as it was well away from all the hussle and bussle of main Waikiki. It was nice to get back to a quiet place of Waikiki after a day of noise and Fun on the beach.Location is close to shopping centre and ala moanna beach area which is quieter than Waikiki beach.Hilton Hawaii Hotel complex is accross the road and easy to get to, to use the shops and beach.The staff were very helpfull all the time. We would definately go back there again.

We just got back from a trip where we stayed at the Holiday Inn, the Prince and the Mandarin. The Holiday Inn was the cheapest (111$/night) and the worse of the bunch. Its similar to a motel 8 experience. The staff are responsive and friendly. The tour lady was nice. The bell hops enthusiastic. Wireless Internet access is free. The pool is small but seldom crowded. The workout room is adequate and clean. Our room was tiny and you could tell the place had its share of visitors. I would recommend this budget place for 2 nights or less. And then if you must stay longer, go to a higher end place for 20-30$ more. You will notice the difference.All in all, this place was a bit overpriced for what they offer. It should be in the range of 60 to 70$. Yet we had no hassles, average service, etc.

This was a terrible experience from start to end. We checked into our room which was booked as a king or queen to our surprise it was two small double beds. Went down to the front desk and was switched with a big hassle and lots of people making us feel like we were putting them out. When we got to our new room it had a terrible smell with cigarette burns in all the covers and even stained towels. As well, the window was cracked and barley closed but gave some fresh air and might help with the mold growing in the bathroom. We were booked and paid for two nights and ended up leaving early and going to a different hotel. We have stayed at lots of three and some two star hotels but this was the worst hotel we have ever been in. The service was so bad no one even asked us why we were going to a different hotel and we could not book a tour with them as they would not help us. Spend the extra $25 or $50 and stay someplace nicer.

This hotel surprised us both for value and comfort. Granted, the rooms are pretty dated (the ancient hairdryer/vacuum attachment needs to go), but we got a King Superior room w/balcony on the Penthouse floor with a view of the ocean for $117/night. Laundry facilities are dirt cheap and although we didn't use the fitness room, it did look like it had some good equipment. It's off the beaten path, but there are still some great local and chain restaurants about 5 minutes away. Also walking distance to the Ala Moana Shopping Mall.

Great stay the holiday inn waikiki, very clean, near to restaurants, shopping, hwy. laundry facility good. easy to find, on main road, yet our room was very quiet. we were busy with so many activities we were only in the room at night, totally met our needs.

If you want a clean, safe hotel for a short stay this is fine. If you want a place to have a week long Waikiki vacation, forget it unless you are broke and need this price. If you have money and really want to stay here, get one of the two penthouse rooms. We booked online at the Holiday Inn web site and got a great price per night, pre-paid. So what I'm writing below is not great, but the price for being near Waikiki was great. Next time we will trade this location for higher prices.It's near Waikiki, not in Waikiki proper. You are at the very very end of Waikiki, across the street. You can't cross the street because it is fenced down the middle. You have to walk to get around it, then go through another hotel property to find the beach. Watch out while crossing six and four lanes of traffic on your beach journey. This takes about 20 minutes each way. Bring a cart/daypack for anything that you want to take instead of carrying it in the hot sun. Unless you go to the lagoon next to the other hotel, you will have to walk very far to the actual Waikiki beach.Some of the Holiday Inn staff were great, and some of them could have cared less. We called from the room about pool towels. We were told that they were in the workout room next to the pool. Kids went into the pool, I went over to get towels. No towels. I called from the workout room and was told that I had to now go down to the main floor and get them from the front desk. So I went there soaked, in the elevator and into the front lobby.Don't use the laundry room to dry your swimsuits and beach towels. There is no place to sit and watch your stuff and no room to stand. Most people stood outside in the hallway watching others go to their rooms.The rooms are small, really small. You have about 2 feet around the ends of the beds to walk, and about 3 feet on the far side where the table/window/lanai is. The pictures on the web were taken with a fisheye lens. The living area with two beds is about 12x18 feet. That holds two double beds, a lamp table, a desk, a dresser and a table with two chairs. We all had to stand up to move someone from one side to the other.The bathrooms have no fans. If more than two of you take showers, be ready to breathe humid bathroom air until it soaks into the bedroom area. You can also imagine what other smells (trying to keep this clean yet real) are also NOT going to leave the bathroom and surround you in the bedroom area. Parking after 6pm is not good. There are about 30 parking spaces for 199 rooms. That's 30 spaces for parking AFTER the resturaunt closes. Otherwise it's about 18 spaces, which are usually all filled. This is not a joke. We learned the hard way to show up early to park and then walk for the rest of the night.As of 2/05 they have highspeed internet, for $20. Local calls are a $1.

While visiting Oahu between February 22 and March 1, 2005, my wife and stayed at the Hoiliday Inn Waikiki. The hotel was centrally located for the sites that we wanted to see and the places to eat. The only minus thing I have is the charge for parking which was $8 a day, but never had to go looking for a spot to park even when coming in late at night.If we were to go back again we would diffenitly stay at this Hotel.

We just spent 10 days there and the next trip to Waikiki we will automatically stay there for the following reasons Great Location, clean and quite rooms, friendly staff, The best beach in Waikiki is only a 5 minute walk (same beach that the Hilton Hawaii Village use), TheBus stop in right in front of hotel, $5 dollar breakfast buffet (a good deal), Only problem I found with the hotel is that the rooms are small (Europe /Asian size). A way around these small rooms is to get a room with a balcony and if you want a quite room ask for a room thats not on the street side but on the backside on a upper floor (we heared no noise in our 10 day stay, which is nice in Waikiki). The reveiws I have read on this hotel have been accurate. IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR AN AFFORTABLE QUALITY ROOM WITH A GREAT LOCATION THIS IS THE PLACE

We stayed here in December 2004 and this isn't a bad hotel for what we paid - £80 per night.Reasonable sized room with a fridge and a coffee maker (with complimentary coffee each day), large safe (remember to take the activator with you when you check out!). If you want a quiet room go for one with a balcony as they are on the highest floors.All the staff we met were friendly and efficient.The only disadvantage we found with the hotel was trying to find it! Although it's just off Ala Moana Boulevard it took us at least fifteen minutes of driving around the area to find it.

We just returned from an 8 night stay at HI Waikiki, which we earned with Priority Club points. Found the hotel to be clean and practical but nothing fancy. Our room had an awesome view of the Hilton Hawaiian Village and a little slice of ocean, but no lanai, unfortunately. Also had a fridge, coffeemaker, safe -- hotel has a small pool, laundry facility, gift shop and a travel desk (which we didn't use).Staff is very friendly. This HI has no restaurant but has sublet their restaurant space to a chinese buffet, which is OK for quick lunch but not great for breakfast. Coffee house down the street was just fair -- a much better breakfast can be had 2 blocks north at Eggs n' Things! Also, look through the free coupon books found all over the island for a buy one get one free coupon for Singha Thai, 1 block left on Ala Moana. This was my favorite restaurant on Oahu!This is a quiet place, out of the main hustle and bustle but convenient to the convention center, shopping, beach and several good restaurants and only 1 mile from "main" Waikiki. If I were staying for business, I'd be very happy with this hotel. However I might have been less pleased if I were with kids since there isn't really anything here for them. This is not a resort hotel but it doesn't have a resort hotel pricetag, either.

We stayed here Dec 03. We had a standard room which was pleasant but as very few of the rooms have a balcony, there is no opportunity to sit out for a drink/bite to eat. Location is some walk from beach but reasonably close to the large Ala Moana shopping mall that we liked. Pool was small and on the first floor above the reception and was in shadow for much of the day, as a result there were only one or two people using it. Would we stay here again? No, it was reasonably cheap for Waikiki, but we felt the lack of balcony, small concrete pool area and location let this hotel down. I have also stayed at the Royal Garden which we prefer. The rooms are slighlty older and some need refurb, but all their rooms have balconies and the pool area and entrance area is lovely. I think its better value for the price. However, this year we are splurging alittle and have booked the Beachfront sheraton waikiki on priceline, its about $20-30 more but a lovely to be on the beach and right in the middle of things and rooms have balconies!

Stayed here one night recently due to a killer promotion with my frequent flyer program and found the place to be clean, centrally located and friendly. The front desk must've known the deal I was getting and pestered me to upgrade when we checked in but we stuck to the original booking. Parking is a bit tight in their lot, but then all of Waikiki is in the same boat. Answer: rent only a sub compact when in Honolulu. I would stay here again.

I read reviews on TripAdvisor and found consistent info on the Holiday Waikiki. So I chose to stay there and check it out for myself. My family and I stay ther from June 25th to july 4th, 2004. My only concern was that the parking was not great. I was confirmed with a 6 bucks a day rate, but was charged 8 per day, even though I advised the desk clerk, Bo, that I was confirmed at 6.00 per day. She explained that the management company had raised the rate since I booked. I think they should have honored my original rate. My second concern was as mentioned in other reviews was the rooms were a bit small. But for the price..I had 2 double beds and balcony (thank God)..I was pleased. The staff was friendly and helpful. The rooms were clean and the furniture was fine. The pool was also kept clean as well as the rest of the property. Housekeeping was great too. They seemed to know just when we went out and cleaned the room immediately. I would give the property an A-. Next trip the wife wants to stay at the Hawaii Hilton Village, but I would not rule out The Holiday Inn. The rates enabled me to stay in Oahu longer. And I can always cross the street to the Hilton. I thouhgt HI was a good value..I don't like to spend a lot of time in the room anyway. Just need a clean, comfortable place to sleep and shower.  As for dining, I never tried the Chinese American restaurant in front of the hotel, but just down the street..The Wailana Coffee Shop is open 24/7 and has great food and great prices. My regards to the Staff and a hello to Bo. Aloha

We stayed at the Holiday Inn Waikiki the last part of June 2004 for several nights and found the hotel exactly what we expected. Standard Holiday Inn style hotel. A good value for the money. It is located across the street from the Hilton Hawaiian Village Hotel and within easy walking distance to Waikiki Beach as well as to restaurants, stores, and fast food joints. The rooms were clean and comfortable but a little small. No lani (balcony) but the windows did open. The traffic noise from the Ala Moana was fairly noisy even up on the 15th floor so we kept the windows closed and the a/c on which was a little noisy itself. We had a partial ocean view between the two Hilton Towers which was a pleasant surprise. The pool was ok - it has limited sun exposure due to all the condo towers around it. Our vacation also had us booked into the Ohana East Hotel at the latter part of the week and for the same amount of money we found the Ohana East to be a better hotel. Given a choice next time between the Holiday Inn or the Ohana East we would choose the Ohana East.

On May 2, 2004 after a 7 day cruise around the islands we went to Holiday Inn for 5 nights. We wanted a place to stay that was quiet, close to the beach, resturants, and shopping, and also a reasonable price. The Holiday Inn met all our expectations and more.First, we were very happy to see how easy it was toget to the registration desk with all our luggage.(The night before the cruise we stayed at a more pricey hotel and that was a horrible experience.} The people here were very friendly and helpful. They even have a small area to buy tickets to site seeing and activity places. All the help was friendly and helpful.Our room was very nice with a king size bed. There was a lot of storage space for your items. There was a refrigerator, safe, ironing board and iron, and coffee pot. The shower had plenty of water pressure. The room was clean and kept clean while we were there. Although our room was near garbage trucks and a construction business, it was still very quiet. This was very important to me as I am a light sleeper. The view out the window was terrible, but that was not important to me. I could have changed rooms if I wanted to like my sister did, but I was quite happy where we stayed as I just wanted to sleep there.As others mentioned there is a resturant right below the hotel that has meal buffets. The food is good and the price is cheaper than at home. But there are even better resturants just a short walk away. Also the international market place is just a short walk away. Although the hotel is not on the beach, the beach is very close. We mostly walked to the one at the military hotel. It was very nice. Also there are many ABC stores nearby.(like a Turkey-Hill or 7 -11) We bought soda there to take to our room. Also we bought equipment to go snorkeling there. They have the best prices.WE got our reservation for our hotel room way ahead on the internet. We payed 87.50 per night plus taxes. We thought there may be problems when we got there getting our room on the internet.But there were done. We didn't even have to show anything they were already expecting us and could not have been nicer. In fact we were surprised to find out that we now belonged to the priority club for booking this way. That gave us free coffee and newspapers in our room everyday. Also it gave us automatic right to late check out. That was real nice since our flight home was in the evening. Also they put our luggage in a locked room for us until it was time to leave. When we departed for the airport a shuttle bus just drove up under their carport to pick us up. (We paid ahead for round trip ticket to airport) My sister and her husband also stayed at this hotelwhile we did and they were very pleased also.The only negative thing they thought was that the parking was limited, but they always found a spot for their rental car.I think one of the best features of the hotel is it's ideal location.I would recommend this hotel to all except those who prefer to have a luxery one. If I ever get to Hawaii again, I would stay there again. Although we wanted a reasonable price hotel, this was not the cheapest in Hawaii, but we are so thankful that we picked this one.

I stayed in Holiday Inn Waikiki on my first arrival in Hawaii on 8th May 2004 .Then i went to Big Island.when i was back to Oahu, i stayed in Holiday Inn Waikiki for two more nights on 14th and 15th May,as included in my air + accommodation package (approximate USD$65 per room per night). If you are not keen to go to the beach, this hotel location is great.it is close to Ala Moana Shopping Centre.There are a number of good restaurants in walking distance (incl china buffet unch USD6.99 ),even a 24 hours open coffee house.I stayed in a standard room, so no balcony, no views.but it is clean.i just hate smoking rooms/floors, really bad odour... but when i booked the hotel, non-smoking king sized bed rooms all were booked out.Friendly reception.i like the gift shop very much.good price, good gifts, it even sell stamps.i could just drop the postcards (with stamps) that i wanted to send out in the reception - very convenient then.parking costs USD8 per day.late check-out till 5pm costs USD40 + tax.

My wife and I booked only one night here, May 4, the day we arrived in Oahu because we were heading for the North Shore the next morning. Our one night was such a positive start to our vacation we would have been comfortable staying there much longer. A bit difficult to find coming from the airport - you can't see the Holiday Inn sign heading west on Ala Moana. Don't even try - we basically knew where it was but we still couldn't find it right away. Just pass the Hilton entrance on the right then get yourself headed east on Ala Moana (back toward the airport) and then you can't miss it. They should have a higher sign so tired travellers can see it both ways on Ala Moana.As tired as we were (12 hours of flying and 7 hour time difference from home) we were soon laughing out load at the overly enthusiastic parking attendant. She was so super friendly we perked right up (3am body time) and decided to check out the Hilton grounds which are beautiful and only a 3 minute walk away. The tropical walk got us into the Hawaii spirit right away.As HI priority members we were easily able to get a 2pm check out time so we were able to go out for the entire moring and early afternoon for site seeing then come back and check out before heading North - very convienent.The Holiday Inn itself was clean, bright and great value. It isn't a resorty type place but neither is the price and its just a short walk away from the beach, good restaurants, shops, etc. We were glad we chose the HI to kick start our vacation in Hawaii.

This place was perfect for anyone on a budget. Booked this place at $110/night for 7 nights less than a week before arriving directly at their website. Instead of spending a ton of money at the higher-end places, save it to spend at the swap meet or Zippy's. Literally across the street from the Hilton Hawaiian. Went to the China Buffet downstairs more than we liked due to an injured family member. McDonalds & ABC Superette is closer than the Hilton. 240-store Ala Moana mall is closer than the beach.We ordered a crib and it was there waiting for us, but you need to bring blankets & such. Nice little exercise room: recline LifeCycle, 4-station stack, & sit-up bench. One computer with high-speed internet access is available in the lobby during the day. Somewhat limited parking, but you're taken care of.

I stayed at this hotel as part of a Suntrips package. It was a GREAT hotel. Attentive staff, extremely clean and up-to-date. Great location in Waikiki. Enjoyed the view from the backside of the hotel, opposite Ala Moana Blvd. Try to get a room with a balcony. We were on the penthouse floor and it was delightful. Highly recommend this Holiday Inn. Made my stay very enjoyable. I will return.

The Holiday Inn- Waikiki is a great value and a great location. My husband and I stayed here first week in September for four nights and had a great time. We got a rate of $84 per night, which is a great value for a hotel located only five minute walk to Waikiki beach. The lobby was beautiful and the staff is very friendly and professional. This was the first Holiday Inn that I stayed at that didn't give discount coupons for breakfast (like the Holiday Inn Soho). We stayed away from the Chinese buffet restaurant attached to the hotel. We preferred going to the coffee shop around the corner to eat (I think its called Wailana Coffee Shop). Also a great value at $6.00 per meal. Who says Hawaii can't be affordable? We chose not to stay in a resort on the beach because we didn't plan on spending a lot of time on Waikiki beach during the day. We had a lot of site seeing to do (Pearl Harbor, USS Missouri, Diamond Head, etc.). After site seeing during the day, we would walk to the resorts on the beach and have cocktails and watch the sunset. The Royal Hawaiin and Halekelani make the best Mai Tais. For those of you who stay at Holiday Inns frequently, you are used to a good hair dryer in the room. For this hotel stay, bring your hair dryer. The one in the bathroom acts like a reverse vacuum cleaner and looks to be very old. Other than that, great hotel.

Who even knew there is a Holiday Inn in Waikiki? Tucked off in quiet seclusion across the street from the Hilton Hawaiian Village, it provides the same convenience as larger hotels for about $100/night. Parking is $6/day - another bargain. There's a pool, a great exercise facility, and the China Buffet Restaurant is open very late. But best of all, this is where the flight attendants for China Airlines stay during layovers. Nothing more need be said.
